_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Thrifty Ice Cream, a Division of Rite Aid Corporation, is located at 34.068333 and -118.068056.  Thrifty Ice Cream has developed a risk management program to address the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735-2785). Thrifty Ice Cream is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  Thrifty Ice Cream staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using anhydrous ammonia.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Thrifty Ice Cream has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training, reputable contractors, and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Refrigeration Process. Thrifty Ice Cream policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  Thrifty Ice Cream is also coordinated with the Los Angeles County Fire Department, Health Hazardous Materials Division serving the City of El Monte area, which provides additional emergency response expertise. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Thrifty Ice Cream's primary activities encompass production of ice cream and frozen desert products.  Ammonia (anhydrous), used as a refrigerant, is the only regulated substance present at Thrifty Ice Cream.  The maximum inventory of ammonia (anhydrous) is 40,700 pounds and is contained within a single, 2 stage, refrigeration system serving the various production and process areas within the Thrifty Ice Cream, El Monte ice cream plant.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst case analysis has been defined for the cover

ed process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook. 

 

Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary

Two alternative case release scenarios were modeled.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook. 



RISK CONSIDERATIONS

Although the use of anhydrous ammonia for the refrigeration process has inherent potential risks, and worst case release scenarios can potentially reach the community, Thrifty Ice Cream has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make the worst case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.



In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a release of a regulated substance:

 - The system has alarms and interlocks

 - The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

 - Gas detection is in place to notify individuals if a leak occurs.

 - The equipment modeled for the release is located in a room within the building; an appropriate, yet conservative mitigation factor was accounted for in the analysis.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Thrifty Ice Cream to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia.

In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed; this includes common practices outlined by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:

 - Process Safety Information

 - Process Hazard Analysis

 - Operating Procedures

 - Training

 - Mechanical Integrity

 - Management of Change

 - Pre-Startup Safety Review

 - Compliance Audits

 - Incident Investigation

 - Employee Participation

 - Hot Work Permit

 - Contractors



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The accident history can be found in the documentation located behind the Incident Investigation Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Thrifty Ice Cream has filed a Unified Contingency Plan with Los Angeles County Fire Department.  This plan includes:

 - Emergency Alarm Procedures

 - Evacuation Procedures

 - Safety and Health Considerations

 - Notification Procedures



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the reports.  Any outstanding recommendations have been addressed since the last PHA was completed.

  

FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

The use of flammable materials at the Thrifty Ice Cream Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 



FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

The use of flammable materials at the Thrifty Ice Cream Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.



EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.7(q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of ammonia wer
e addressed by the PHA and a previous Seismic Assessment.
